description: The purpose of the course is to provide the basic understanding of the Physical Computing paradigm, how different forms of energy (e.g. speed, sound, kinetic, force) can be used as input and output in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) scenarios. The course will cover the fundamental concepts of the Physical Computing paradigm. Students on this course will study the properties and use of standard components such as resistors, diodes, transistors and capacitors but also more complex components such as microcontrollers, sensors, and actuators. They will learn how to apply these components to create standalone interactive circuits that can be integrated into everyday objects, with a didactic focus on physical properties and interaction models. Following on from this, students will learn how to create and print 3D models, and explore the haptic properties of different materials. This will provide the students with the skills for prototyping and building mock-ups of new interactive artefacts and environments. The student should understand how hardware, software and other materials can be combined in the design of computational objects for HCI.
qualifications: use basic electronic components and sensors / actuators to design and construct interactive artifacts and/or environments from scratch
construct more advanced interactive devices or systems based on standalone microcontrollers
utilize 3D printers to print CAD models
prototype a working Physical Computing system according to a project brief provided during class
evaluate and reflect on the work done in class from a technological, user experience and multimodal interaction perspective
support prototype design choices with scientifically grounded arguments, referencing related work in HCI, Psychology, and Physical Computing

description: The course will focus on the main theoretical and practical aspects of multimodal interaction. The course will cover visual, auditory, haptic, and olfactory perception, models of multimodal interaction, psychophysical evaluation methods, and the development of multisensory prototypes.
qualifications: define the basics of human visual, auditory and tactile perception
describe the functionality of state-of-the-art multimodal HCI interfaces
apply psychophysical methods to evaluate human performance with multimodal interfaces
discuss the strengths and weaknesses of multimodal interfaces
generalize and transfer principles of multimodal interaction to new interfaces and environments.
